title: Torque - nonuniform bar with pivot at left end

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A nonuniform bar is attached to a wall by a fixed pivot at its left end, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The bar has length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> and mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. Its mass is distributed such that the bar’s center of mass is a distance <math alttext="L over 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> from the bar’s free end and the bar’s rotational inertia about the pivot is <math alttext="one half M L squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>. A string is attached to the wall and to the bar as shown, holding the bar horizontal.

The bar is shown again in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and the dots in the figure are located at the point of attachment for the string and at the bar’s center of mass.
(a) In Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, draw and label arrows that represent the forces (not components) that are exerted on the bar. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the point at which the force is exerted on the bar.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A nonuniform bar is attached to a wall by a fixed pivot at its left end, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The bar has length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> and mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. Its mass is distributed such that the bar’s center of mass is a distance <math alttext="L over 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> from the bar’s free end and the bar’s rotational inertia about the pivot is <math alttext="one half M L squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>. A string is attached to the wall and to the bar as shown, holding the bar horizontal.

The bar is shown again in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and the dots in the figure are located at the point of attachment for the string and at the bar’s center of mass.
(a) In Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, draw and label arrows that represent the forces (not components) that are exerted on the bar. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the point at which the force is exerted on the bar.

The string is cut, and the bar starts rotating from its initially horizontal position. As the bar rotates, a constant frictional torque of magnitude <math alttext="the fraction 1 over 12, end fraction, times M g L" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><mi>g</mi><mi>L</mi></math> is exerted on the bar by the pivot.

(b) Starting with Newton’s second law in rotational form, derive an expression for the bar’s angular acceleration immediately after the string is cut, when the bar has started to rotate but is still approximately horizontal. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing either a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference book.

(c) On the axes in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the angular acceleration of the bar as a function of the angle between the bar and the horizontal. Take the positive direction to be clockwise. On the vertical axis in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, <math alttext="alpha sub b" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>b</mtext></msub></math> is the magnitude of the angular acceleration derived in part (b).

The bar is returned to the horizontal position. Another string is then attached to the bar, as shown in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. This time, the string is attached to the bar so that it is lined up with the bar’s center of mass. The string is also attached to a higher location on the wall so that it is oriented at the same angle as the original string.
(d) Other than the force exerted by the string, indicate how a force represented in the diagram you drew for part (a) would change, if at all, with the second string attached to the bar and wall as in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. If there would be no changes to any other forces, state this explicitly. Justify your answer.
